page.title: 10Pendomer: Footpaths
page.content: The map shows a number of footpaths and bridleways. Most of these evolved to serve a population which travelled on foot, or occasionally on horseback. One at least was a drove road for taking beasts to market. Now, most are little used and difficult to follow for those who wish to use them. This is not because farmers have deliberately blocked them; rather it is that unused paths across land which is intensively grazed or cultivated soon disappear, or a best become almost impassable in wet weather. Even the dog walkers find them unrewarding - one cannot let a dog loose in a field where there are animals, and dogs are not good with stiles. For horse riders, apart from the often soft or uneven going, there are gates to be opened and shut so they often prefer to keep to the quiet roads.
